The COVID-19 pandemic represents an international healthcare emergency, with exceptional numbers of patients with respiratory failure requiring positive pressure ventilation. The demand for level 3 beds is exceeding capacity nationally and alternative ventilators are being sought. Anaesthetic machines, with in-built ventilators represent one of these alternatives. At Broomfield, we have a mixture of Dräger and GE anaesthetic machines, which are of varying levels of suitability for this role. As a result they are being deployed for use in the planned ICU surge areas.
This usage is “off-label” as has been expressly advised by both Dräger and GE.

The use of anaesthetic machines for long-term (“ICU”) ventilation is an exceptional practice and is only to be done during the periods of exceptional demand for ventilated ICU beds. The decision to intubate and ventilate a patient will be made by the on-call ICU consultant with or without assistance from the PFI ITU/Triage consultant. That patient will be intubated by the MERIT and transferred to either our main ICU, or one of the ICU surge areas. Anaesthetic machines will be used as ventilators in the surge areas. These machines may be any of the following: Dräger Perseus or Atlan, GE Aestiva, Aisys or Aespire.

The specific indication for use of the anaesthetic machine will be respiratory failure unresponsive to non-invasive oxygenation strategies and therefore requiring tracheal intubation and ventilation in a patient where there is no capacity in a critical care area for ventilation with a standard ICU ventilator.

data.text: Summary of Specific Variations between ICU Ventilators and Anaesthetic Machine Ventilators
Common Differences

Anaesthetic machines and ICU ventilators are designed to different working principles and have different user interfaces. Medical personnel using the device must have received training and be familiar with the device.

Anaesthetic machines default to manual (either patient breathing or “hand bagging”) ventilation when first turned on AND do not have a back-up ventilation mode that starts when apnoea is detected in this mode. They do however, have apnoea alarms to alert the user to the absence of patient breathing.

The breathing circuit is a circle system. This system maintains the expired patient gas in the circuit and circulates it through a carbon dioxide absorbing substance (“soda lime”) before adding “fresh gas flow (FGF)” to maintain the desired fraction of oxygen and returning it to the inspiratory limb of the circuit. This allows high efficiency when using inhaled anaesthetic agents but, does not tolerate leaks or high airway pressures. There are a number of follow-on issues created by this.

The gas controls on the anaesthetic machine only govern the fresh gas flow – fresh gas (oxygen and air) which is added to the breathing system (ostensibly to replace the oxygen taken up by the patient and the carbon dioxide removed by the soda lime). There is no direct control over the inspired fraction of oxygen (FO ). The
i
FiO is a measured and displayed parameter on all machines, and should be used as the reference by which the FGF rates (L/min) and proportion of O : Air in the
FGF are adjusted.
The response of this system to changes in the oxygen concentration can be slow (e.g. if low total FGF is being used). Thus, if a rapid change in FO is required the
i
O flow should be increased, and the total FGF e.g. patient desaturates after
suctioning, current FGF 50:50 O :Air, total FGF 4L/min – solution, increase O to
100:0, increase total FGF to 10L/min.

If the FGF is too low (not enough oxygen supplied to replace that being absorbed by the patient) or there is a leak in the circuit then the ventilator will not deliver the volume of gas expected on inspiration. There is no compensation for this, but alarms will sound. The same effect can be created by suctioning the patient with insufficient FGF.
FGF is recommended to be 150% of the patient's minute volume (MV), however, this value is not practical due to limitations on the oxygen supply that can be maintained.
The lack of leak compensation (point 4.6), means that the machines are also not suitable for the nebulisation route of drug delivery.
The lack of leak compensation (point 4.6), means that suctioning the airway with closed suction might exacerbate atelectasis. For this reason FGF may need to be increased around suctioning.

If there is a rise in the airway pressure there is no release valve to protect the patient, the pressure will continue to rise, until the pressure threatens the machine (c. 110cmHO). The machine will stop applying further pressure (inspiratory cut off, cycle to expiration), but there is no ability to open the patient circuit to the atmosphere. P /P alarms must be set at appropriate levels and responded to
max peak
urgently when they are triggered.

Anaesthetic machines utilise “soda lime” to absorb the patient's expired carbon dioxide and allow the safe use of low flows during anaesthesia with no rebreathing of expired carbon dioxide by the patient. The efficiency of this process deteriorates and ultimately the soda lime becomes exhausted (no longer absorbs a sufficient

amount of carbon dioxide to prevent re-breathing of carbon dioxide by the patient). Our local policy is to change the soda lime when the inspired fraction of carbon dioxide (FCO ) is 1.0kPa. There is a visual guide to soda lime exhaustion, Dräger
i
CLIC disposable canisters start off white, and change to violet, or Intersurgical Spherasorb starts off pink and changes to white.
None of the anaesthetic machines in use long term ventilation in surge capacity ICU areas have pipeline or cylinder supply of nitrous oxide (N O). This may lead to
alarm triggers for absent or low pressure N O, but these will not interfere with the
function of the machine.

At each bed space where an anaesthetic machine is being used to ventilate a patient there must be an alternative method of patient ventilation must be available. This will be either a self-inflating bag/mask device or Mapleson C (“Waters' circuit”), which can be attached to the wall oxygen supply.
The anaesthetic machine has a mount on the back for an oxygen cylinder – a cylinder must be attached to this and that cylinder must have at least 50kPa pressure remaining.

Anaesthetic machines do not warm or humidify the gas being inspired by the patient. Therefore, in addition to any device used to filter the patient's expired gas, there must be a heat and moisture exchange device. At MEHT these two functions are combined in an heat and moisture exchange filter (HMEF), which is attached to the patient end of the two limb anaesthetic circuit. Beyond the HMEF is a flexible catheter mount with a closed suction system that attaches to the patient's tracheal tube.

The adjustable pressure-limiting valve (APL) only has a role in limiting the airway pressure during manual or spontaneous ventilation. It has no effect on the maximum airway pressure during mechanical ventilation. When mechanical ventilation is in use, the APL valve should be at position 0cmHO.

The alarms on anaesthetic machines are designed for the operator to be within 4m of the device. Not only does there need to be an operator close to the machine at all times, but the alarm volume must not be changed.

Anaesthetic machines have pre-set alarm ranges for all measured and delivered variables. These ranges may not be appropriate for all patients and should be adjusted to reflect the individual's physiology and maintain safety. After a system reset/system check, the alarm ranges will return to the machine defaults – they will need re-adjusting to the patient specific levels.

Gas analysis on anaesthetic machines relies on side-stream sampling of the inspired and expired gas. The sampling rate is approximately 150mL/min, via a 2m long narrow bore tube. The sampled gas is then analysed. Both of these steps result in a “lag time” between sampling of the gas and display of the gas analysis (the transit time and response time). Practically, this means there may be a 30-60s delay between changes to the patient's inspired or expired gas concentrations and a change in the displayed values on the anaesthetic machine.

If anaesthetic machines are used to ventilate patients for ICU purposes and it is necessary to use inhalational agents (e.g. sevoflurane, isoflurane) to maintain sedation, it is possible that small residual amounts of that agent could remain between patients. This means that there is a risk of triggering malignant hyperpyrexia (MH). Where anaesthetic machines are not attached to scavenging, there would also be a risk to staff working in that area. These risk needs to be addressed where possible by:
Enquiring about personal and family history of malignant hyperpyrexia;
Minimising the use of inhalational agents to sedate ICU patients;
Routinely flushing machines with oxygen between patients when an inhalational agent has been used;

Applying charcoal “MH filters” to both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the anaesthetic circuit when ventilating a new patient with a positive personal or family history of malignant hyperpyrexia.

System test – ideally an anaesthetic machine undergoes a full system check at least once every  hours. This is not practicable when ventilating ICU patients, so this frequency has been decreased to once every  hours. This should be reviewed on each morning ICU ward round, and a plan for performing the check made as required. Refer to Appendix 2 for the Procedure for Performing an Anaesthetic Machine Reset and System Test.
Dräger Specific Issues

The breathing bag on the anaesthetic machine acts as a reservoir during both spontaneous and mechanical ventilation. This means that it moves (expands and contracts) in response to patient ventilation. This is a useful visual aid to confirm that ventilation is occurring. If the bag collapses there is insufficient fresh gas flow or a leak in the breathing circuit. Potentially a 2L breathing bag may be insufficient, 3L breathing bags should be made available if this occurs.

Water trap – “Waterlock 2”, this protects the gas measurement system from excess humidity in the gas sample. This must not be allowed to fill beyond half full, so requires 12 hourly review (4 hourly if excess water has been problematic), and any excess water removed as detailed in appendix

The Dräger Perseus and Atlan anaesthetic machines use the same Dräger CLIC disposable soda lime canisters. These are changed once the FiCO is greater than 1.0kPa. These do not require immediate changing, and there is a gradual increase in FCO as the soda lime capacity to absorb CO is exhausted. There are ODPs
i
always available to come to the ICU area to change the canister.
GE Specific Issues
The breathing bag on the anaesthetic machine is NOT a reservoir of gas during mechanical ventilation. It will NOT move during mechanical ventilation.
All GE anaesthetic machines use refillable soda lime canisters. The soda lime is to bechanged once the FCO is greater than 1.0kPa. These do not require immediate
i
changing, and there is a gradual increase in FiCO as the soda lime capacity to absorb CO is exhausted. There are ODPs always available to come to the ICU
area to change the soda lime.
Anaesthetic Machines as Long Term Ventilators Standard Operating Procedure

table_items.text: Anaesthetic Machines as Long Term Ventilators Standard Operating
For every shift, in each area where patients are being ventilated on anaesthetic machines there must be a member of staff recognised as familiar with the machines in use.

Prior to use, the anaesthetic machine is to be checked as per the manufacturer's recommendations. This will include fitting a new anaesthetic circuit and gas sampling line, leak testing the circuit, gas supply, both via wall supply and cylinder and any alarm systems present.

An humidity and moisture exchange filter (HMEF) is to be fitted to the patient end of the circuit system. This is to maintain humidity in the patient's inspired gas and remove it from the gas returning to the machine, it also prevents contamination of the circuit with material exhaled by the patient.
Alarm parameters must be set to appropriate levels for the patient currently being ventilated and monitored.

The breathing circuit must be checked for excess moisture once every four hours, if excess moisture is present it should be drained as described in Appendix 1; Procedure for Emptying Water from the Breathing Circuit.

The gas sampling water trap must be checked for excess moisture once every twelve hours (once every 4 hours if problems have been previously noted), if excess moisture is present it should be drained as described in Appendix 1; Procedure for Emptying Water from the Gas Monitoring Water Trap.
During mechanical ventilation, the APL (adjustable pressure limiting) valve is to be set to 0cmH2O.
Alarm volumes must not be changed from 100%.
The risk of triggering Malignant Hyperpyrexia must be considered if inhalational
anaesthetic agents have or are being used to sedate ICU patients.
.Anaesthetic machines in use for ventilating ICU patients require a system reset/check every 72 hours. Refer to Appendix 2, Procedure for Performing an Anaesthetic Machine Reset and System Test.
.Soda lime becomes chemically exhausted and must be replaced once the FCO is greater than 1.0kPa. This will be done by the ODP staff. i 2

What are you proposing to change?
Change in process for ventilating patients with acute respiratory failure when ICU ventilators are not available
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To improve safety for patients and theatre staff and reduce cross contamination of clinical areas and recognise that this is an “off-label” use of the anaesthetic machines.
Who benefits from this change and how?
Patients – all equipment and staffing appropriate for case Staff – ensuring appropriate PPE considered and exposure limited
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No, these guidelines are to ensure that any risks from long-term ventilation of ICU patients with anaesthetic machines are mitigated.
